title: Supply-Chain Obsession Is a Prime Day Gift for Amazon Air
sub_head: Amid a global scramble to regain control over supply chains, the e-commerce giant’s rapidly growing fleet of aircraft could bring it into more direct competition with FedEx and UPS
body:
There is nothing like a pandemic and a European war to highlight the value of logistics. Amazon . com’s growing fleet of planes shows that it is investing hard to deliver—probably at the expense of FedEx , UPS and DHL.
Amazon’s cargo airline currently makes an average of 187 flights a day, compared with 85 in May 2020, according to a biannual analysis led by Joseph Schwieterman, a professor at DePaul University, published late Tuesday.
